skill.name: Article List Processor
skill.summary: Automatically fetches article content from markdown link lists and generates viral-style content
skill.author: wangdefou

security_audit.summary: The skill performs legitimate content processing tasks. Most static findings are false positives due to scanner misinterpretation. JavaScript regex.exec() was flagged as Python exec(), and template literals were flagged as Ruby backticks. Network and file operations are controlled and necessary for the documented functionality. No credential exfiltration or malicious patterns detected.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Line 63 is regex.exec() for parsing markdown links, not Python's exec(). The scanner confused JavaScript regex matching with Python code execution. The code at line 63: 'while ((match = regex.exec(content)) !== null)' is standard regex parsing, not code execution.

The child_process.spawn is imported but only used once at line 198 to run 'npm run skill:verify' for build verification. This is a legitimate tooling command with hardcoded arguments, not user input. No command injection risk exists.

spawn('npm', ['run', 'skill:verify'], {...}) uses arguments as a separate array, preventing injection. The command is hardcoded for the skill's own verification workflow, not arbitrary command execution.
Line 63 is regex.exec(), not process.exec. Scanner incorrectly identified JavaScript regex matching as shell command execution. This is a pattern-matching false positive.

These are JavaScript template literals (backticks for string interpolation), not Ruby/shell backticks for command execution. Examples: line 16 'Loading .env from: ${envPath}' and line 79 'Fetching: ${url}'. These are standard JS template strings for logging and string formatting.

fs.readFileSync and fs.writeFileSync are used for reading input files and writing generated output. These are necessary for the skill's documented functionality. Paths are constructed using path.join with hardcoded directories, not user input. No path traversal risk.

Sync operations are used for simple file I/O in this watcher script. While async would be better for high-throughput scenarios, the blocking is minimal and acceptable for a single-user content processing tool. No denial-of-service risk.

Network access is used to fetch article content from URLs specified in input files. This is the documented core functionality. User-Agent header mimics a browser. 10-second timeout prevents resource exhaustion. No data exfiltration detected.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [LOW] env_access: "Environment variable access (dot notation)" at index.ts:25,26,27
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: process.env accesses ANTHROPIC_API_KEY, ANTHROPIC_BASE_URL, and MOCK_MODE. These are the skill's own configuration values for Anthropic API integration. No credential harvesting or exfiltration patterns found.

dotenv.config loads the local .env file for configuration. This is standard practice for API key management. The .env path is hardcoded to the project root. No security concern for self-configuration.

chokidar.watch monitors the input directory for new markdown files. This is a core feature enabling automated batch processing. The watched path is hardcoded to 'local_inputs/' directory. No arbitrary file watching or enumeration risk.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [LOW] filesystem: "Node.js fs stat operations" at index.ts:17,36,227
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: fs.existsSync is used to verify .env and input file existence before processing. Standard file handling pattern. No unusual file enumeration or reconnaissance detected.
Line 82 is a User-Agent header string containing 'Intel Mac OS X 10_15_7', not an IP address. Scanner likely misidentified the OS version string. No hardcoded IPs found.

No crypto algorithms found in index.ts. Line 326 is 'if (![".md", ".txt"].includes(path.extname(filename).toLowerCase())) return;' - file extension checking, not cryptography. This appears to be a scanner false positive.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] obfuscation: "[HEURISTIC] High file entropy (6.65 bits) - possible binary/encrypted content" at SKILL.md:1
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: SKILL.md is a markdown file with YAML frontmatter and Chinese text. High entropy may come from the YAML section, URLs, or example code blocks. Not obfuscated content - normal documentation structure.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [CRITICAL] obfuscation: "[HEURISTIC] DANGEROUS COMBINATION: Code execution + Network + Credential access" at multiple:1
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: This combination is intentional and necessary for the skill's functionality: network access fetches article content, credentials authenticate with Anthropic API, and controlled file operations save generated output. No malicious exfiltration or command injection patterns detected. This is legitimate content automation, not malware.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [CRITICAL] obfuscation: "[HEURISTIC] DANGEROUS COMBINATION: Network + Credentials + Evasion techniques" at multiple:1
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: The 'evasion techniques' classification appears to be a false positive. The User-Agent header at line 82 is standard web scraping practice to avoid being blocked by anti-bot measures, not evasion for malicious purposes. This is legitimate content fetching for an authorized use case.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] obfuscation: "[HEURISTIC] SUSPICIOUS COMBINATION: Filesystem + Credentials + Network" at multiple:1
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: This pattern describes standard content processing architecture: read input files (filesystem), fetch external content (network), use API credentials (credentials), and write output. This is the documented design of the skill, not a data exfiltration threat.

These are markdown code block fences (```), not Ruby/shell backticks for command execution. The static scanner incorrectly identified markdown documentation as code execution. These are example commands and configuration snippets in the documentation.
Documentation contains example URLs for demonstration purposes. These are public placeholder URLs (example.com), not actual external endpoints. No data exfiltration to external servers detected.
Line 3 of SKILL.md is YAML frontmatter with Chinese description text. No cryptographic algorithms found. Scanner likely misidentified non-ASCII characters or documentation structure.
The unicode escape \u4e00-\u9fa5 in the regex at line 261 is for Chinese character support in filename sanitization. This is legitimate internationalization, not obfuscation.

Reading .env from project root is standard configuration pattern. Console logs at lines 16,18,20 are just status messages, not data access. No exfiltration - .env is loaded locally for API authentication only.

ANTHROPIC_API_KEY is legitimately accessed to authenticate with Anthropic API. This is expected behavior for an AI-powered skill. No credential exfiltration detected - the key is used only for outbound API calls.
chokidar.watch() monitors the INPUT_DIR for new .md/.txt files. This is a core feature for automated batch processing. The watched path is hardcoded. No arbitrary file enumeration or system scanning.
dotenv.config() loads configuration from local .env file. This is standard practice for API key management. No security concern for self-configuration of the skill.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [LOW] filesystem: "Node.js fs stat operations" at index.ts:17,36,227
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: fs.existsSync() is used to check .env and input file existence before processing. Standard file handling pattern. No unusual file enumeration or reconnaissance detected.
path.resolve(__dirname, '../../') is standard pattern to find project root from skill directory. This is controlled path construction, not path traversal. Direction is outward to project root.

The '../' is hardcoded and used for controlled project root discovery. Not user input. Output paths use path.join() with controlled constants (INPUT_DIR, OUTPUT_DIR, ARCHIVE_DIR). No path injection risk.

medium_findings.description: Node.js fs operations for reading/writing files
medium_findings.justification: Necessary for content processing, paths are controlled
Acceptable for single-user batch processing tool

low_findings.description: Fetch API calls for article content
low_findings.justification: Core functionality with timeout and proper headers

low_findings.description: File stat operations for existence checks

content.value_statement: This skill automatically fetches article content from markdown link lists and generates viral-style content using AI. It watches an input folder for new link files and processes them in batch, saving generated content to an output folder.
actual_capabilities: Parses markdown files to extract article titles and links
Fetches full article content from URLs using readability extraction
Generates viral-style content using Anthropic AI models
Watches input folder for new files and processes them automatically
Saves generated content to organized output files with metadata
Archives processed input files after completion
limitations: Requires valid Anthropic API key to generate content
Cannot process URLs that block bots or require authentication
Output quality depends on the AI model and source article quality

use_cases.title: Batch content creation
use_cases.description: Transform collected article links into viral posts in your writing style automatically

use_cases.title: Content repackaging
use_cases.description: Convert multiple article links into original content for newsletters or social media

use_cases.title: Post generation
use_cases.description: Generate multiple social media posts from a list of article links efficiently

prompt_templates.title: Basic batch processing
prompt_templates.scenario: Process a list of article links
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a markdown file with article links in local_inputs/ and the skill will automatically process them

prompt_templates.title: Custom output folder
prompt_templates.prompt: Set OUTPUT_DIR environment variable to change where generated content is saved

prompt_templates.title: Test without API
prompt_templates.prompt: Set MOCK_MODE=true to test the workflow without using AI credits

prompt_templates.title: Specific article processing
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a markdown file with one article link to process it individually

output_examples.input: Create a reading list file with article links in local_inputs/
output: Processing starts automatically when file is detected
Each article is fetched and rewritten in viral style

best_practices: Use descriptive filenames for input files to easily track processing results
Set MOCK_MODE=true first to verify your input file format works correctly
Keep your .env file secure and never commit it to version control
anti_patterns: Do not use this skill to scrape content from sites without permission
Avoid processing articles behind login walls or with anti-scraping measures
Do not rely on this skill for time-sensitive news content that may change

faq.question: What file format does the skill accept?
faq.answer: The skill accepts markdown files with links in [Title](URL) format or numbered list format.

faq.question: How does the skill generate content?
faq.answer: It uses Anthropic AI models to rewrite articles in a viral Defou x Stanley style.

faq.question: Where are the generated files saved?
faq.answer: Generated content is saved to outputs/defou-stanley-posts/ with metadata headers included.

faq.question: Can I process multiple articles at once?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill processes all valid links in a markdown file in batch with concurrency limit.

faq.question: What happens after processing?
faq.answer: Input files are archived to the archive/ folder after processing completes.

faq.question: Do I need an API key?
faq.answer: Yes, ANTHROPIC_API_KEY must be set in the .env file for content generation.
